Title: The science behind the FDA ban on food dye Red No. 3
Description: On Wednesday, the Food and Drug Administration announced it is banning the dye called Red No. 3, a food dye additive in many processed foods, like sodas, sweets and snacks. Recently, it and other dyes were linked to behavior issues in children. But high levels of Red No. 3 were linked to cancer in rats decades ago. So why is the ban happening now? Senior editor and science desk correspondent Maria Godoy answers our questions about Red No. 3 and other dyes that may replace it. Plus, how should parents think about feeding their kids products that may contain Red No. 3 before the ban takes affect.Questions, story ideas or want us to dig into another food science issue? Description: NPR's Ayesha Rascoe speaks with Mars Tekosky, who lost the home she and her family had recently renovated in Altadena, California due to wildfire.

Description: We'll look at how some leaders in some of the countries that are key U.S.-trading partners have prepared for the new Trump administration.

Title: Ceasefire goes into effect in Gaza, Israel says, after initial delay
Description: The Israeli government announced the ceasefire with Hamas would take effect at 11:15 local time, nearly three hours after the originally scheduled time for hostilities to cease. (Image credit: Bashar Taleb)

Description: Former Trump adviser Steve Bannon says he doesn't believe the president-elect will listen to 'tech oligarchs' over the right-wing populist movement that helped him secure another White House term.

Title: Many doctors don't discuss sex after cancer. But survivors wish they would

Description: There are men, women and children on the list of 33 to be released from Gaza. Two are U.S. citizens. Israel is set to free hundreds of prisoners in exchange for them.

Title: This Virginia program helps former foster youth get degrees, at any age
Description: Great Expectations was designed to help people who grew up in foster care get their two-year degrees. And unlike many programs for former foster youth, there are no age limits. (Image credit: Shaban Athuman)

Description: A long-awaited ceasefire in Gaza began after a three-hour delay as Hamas named the three female hostages it plans to free later on Sunday. (Image credit: Jehad Alshrafi)

Description: The deadline for the start of a ceasefire in the Gaza Strip passed as Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Hamas had provided the names of the three hostages it was set to release on Sunday. (Image credit: Oded Balilty)

Title: Trump's border czar says immigration raids will begin next week, including in Chicago
Description: Prospects of a raid in Chicago come just a few weeks after Trump's border czar Tom Homan visited the city and threatened to prosecute the mayor if he did not cooperate. (Image credit: Jos Edelson)

Title: Trump says he'll likely give TikTok a 90-day extension

Description: NPR transcribed more than 2,000 hours of radio communications from the LA fires. It shows hydrants going dry and first responders fighting the fires despite scarce resources. (Image credit: Brian van der Brug)

Title: South Korean court orders formal arrest of President Yoon over martial law decree
Description: South Korea's impeached president, Yoon Suk Yeol, faces possible imprisonment over his declaration of martial law last month. The formal arrest comes days after he was apprehended. (Image credit: Ahn Young-joon)

Title: U.S. pays $590 million to Moderna to speed up development of bird flu vaccine

Title: In India, a police volunteer is convicted of rape and murder of a trainee doctor
Description: A court found a police volunteer guilty of the rape and murder of a 31-year-old trainee doctor, a crime that sparked protests and hospital strikes amid concerns over lack of safety for women. (Image credit: Bikas Das)

Description: The Israeli government approved a ceasefire deal that could bring an end to the 15 months of war in Gaza. It's slated to go into effect Sunday morning.

Description: Syrians are still celebrating the fall of the Bashar Al-Assad regime, but that enthusiasm is tempered these days.

Description: We look at what the Department of Justice has and hasn't done on war crimes under outgoing Attorney General Merrick Garland.

Description: Even as an anti-immigrant president takes office in the United States, migrants are moving north. NPR asks, why?

Description: NPR's Scott Simon speaks with Yossi Mekelberg of Chatham House's Middle East and North Africa Program, about the Israeli political response to a negotiated ceasefire between Israel and Hamas.

Title: More teens say they're using ChatGPT for schoolwork, a new study finds
Description: According to the survey, 26% of students ages 13-17 are using the artificial intelligence bot to help them with their assignments. (Image credit: EyeEm Mobile GmbH)

Description: Insurers are deploying private firefighters amid the Los Angeles wildfires. Are they an added bonus for all — or only for those who can afford them? (Image credit: Justin Sullivan)

Title: In Lebanon, these Palestinian refugees sew designs from a homeland they've never seen
Description: In a workshop in an infamous refugee camp in Beirut, Palestinian women practice an ancient art form — as a livelihood, and also as therapy. The designs come from a homeland most have never seen. (Image credit: Dalia Khamissy for NPR)

Title: These are the U.S. citizens held hostage in Gaza
Description: Seven of the nearly 100 hostages held in Gaza are U.S. citizens, several of whom are confirmed dead. (Image credit: Hostages and Missing Families Forum)

Description: Cian Lawlor's father was dispatched to the Palisades Fire just over a week ago and he's been working it ever since. The 11-year-old had some questions for his dad. (Image credit: Jaleh Lawlor)

Description: In South Africa a months long stand-off between police and illegal miners in an abandoned gold mine comes to end, with close to 80 found dead in grim recovery operation. (Image credit: LINDA GIVETASH)

Title: A Dangerous Ride on Top of a Train in Mexico
Description: The incoming Trump administration has promised sweeping deportations of undocumented people and little empathy for those seeking refuge in the U.S. Despite that, migrants continue to make the dangerous journey north through Mexico to get to the U.S. border. We hop on a freight train with some migrants to find out why.

Title: The birds are back.' Resilience in the ruins of the Palisades fire
Description: Will Rogers State Historic Park is a vast stretch of natural space in the Santa Monica Mountains. It's a treasure to Angelenos. People get married there, picnic there, and have kids' birthday parties on the great lawn.The park's namesake, Will Rogers, was a vaudeville performer, radio and movie star, and was known as America's 'cowboy philosopher.' Title: Immigrants and advocacy organizations brace for Trump's Day One actions

Description: Part of the cease-fire agreement between Israel and Hamas involves the return of Israeli hostages that have been held in Gaza for more than a year. Their families are relieved, but the hostages have a long road to recovery once they're back home.

Title: Why Australian Open live streams look like Wii tennis — and what it means for sports
Description: The Australian Open's animated tennis livestreams are making a splash. U.S. leagues have used similar technology to put Simpsons on the football field and superheroes on ice skates. (Image credit: Australian Open TV/Screenshot by NPR)

Description: If you've paid attention to the coming inauguration, TikTok drama and the Princess of Wales' health, you'll do pretty well this week.

Description: The National Park Service won't be doing crowd size estimations anymore, including for President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration.

Title: A student in Gaza is afraid to hope that this time the ceasefire will be real
Description: For Shaymaa Ahmed, a 21-year-old engineering student in Gaza, a cease-fire means she can finally mourn her own family. (Image credit: Youssef Alzanoun)

Title: Gaza engineering student reacts to the ceasefire deal between Hamas and Israel
Description: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with 22-year-old engineering student Shaimaa Ahmed in Gaza about how she feels about the news of the ceasefire deal between Hamas and Israel.

Title: Jeff Bezos' Blue Origin launches massive New Glenn rocket on first test flight
Description: The rocket was supposed to launch Monday, but ice buildup caused a delay. It's built to haul spacecraft and eventually astronauts to orbit and also the moon. (Image credit: John Raoux)

Title: America's place in the world during a second Trump term
Description: Confirmation hearings for Trump's cabinet picks are in full swing on Capitol Hill with a number of them appearing before the Senate this week.Nominees including Pam Bondi, Trump's pick to run the Justice Department, John Ratcliffe, his pick to run the CIA, and Florida Senator Marco Rubio Trump's nominee for Secretary of State have all answered questions about what they'll do and what they won't do if confirmed.Rubio and Ratcliffe will play key foreign policy roles under the 47th president.Those are the people, but what do they tell us about the policy?For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.orgEmail us at <a href='mailto:considerthis@...

Title: Israel and Hamas Reach A Deal to End the War in Gaza
Description: A ceasefire deal has been announced that would end more than 15 months of war between Israel and Hamas in Gaza. We learn about the details, how the agreement was reached and hear reaction from Israelis and Palestinians. We also look at what the war has meant for both sides and for the Middle East region. For more coverage of this conflict and the latest developments, please come back to this feed. You can also go to npr.org/mideastupdates (Image credit: Dawoud Abo Alkas)

Title: Flags to be raised for Trump's inauguration, despite half-staff order for Carter's death
Description: The president-elect had expressed concern that Democrats seemed happy to see the flag lowered during the inauguration ceremony despite the tradition of lowering flags after a president's death. (Image credit: Allison Robbert-Pool)

Title: Here's what's in the ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas
Description: The Israel-Hamas ceasefire deal announced Wednesday is intended to end the most intense fighting ever between these bitter rivals. More broadly, the Gaza war unleashed a series of dramatic changes.

Title: Skiers hit the slopes in Lebanon despite turmoil
Description: Ski season has kicked off in the Mediterranean country of Lebanon. Devoted skiers are coming to the slopes despite turmoil in the country.

Title: LA's Magic Castle offers a brief escape during the wildfires
Description: A Los Angeles institution spared from the flames gives back to the community with donations and magic tricks to lift evacuees' spirits. (Image credit: Ryan Kellman)

Title: Trump's Cabinet pick for secretary of transportation is Sean Duffy. Here's what to know
Description: While some of President-elect Trump's cabinet nominees faced sharp questioning this week, Sean Duffy received a friendly welcome in his confirmation hearing to be secretary of transportation. (Image credit: Samuel Corum)

Title: L.A. turns attention to the potential for crime amid fires
Description: In the LA fire zones, law enforcement is promising to crack down on looting, fraud and other crimes. Some residents have hired security or are staying in their houses to watch the neighborhood.

Title: Israel and Hamas agree on phased ceasefire in Gaza
Description: Israel and Hamas have reached an agreement to end the fighting in Gaza. The U.S. played a key role in the deal, which involves a multi-phase ceasefire.

Title: How do you ensure good luck on Lunar New Year? NPR wants to know
Description: The Lunar New Year falls on Jan. 29 this year. NPR wants to know what traditions you uphold to ensure good luck in the year to come. (Image credit: Nhac Nguyen)

Title: LA fires are still raging, but forecasters expect calmer winds in the coming days
Description: It was another day of fierce winds gusting to 65 mph in mountainous areas of Los Angeles and Ventura counties, but weather more conducive to firefighting operations is expected soon. (Image credit: Valerie Macon)

Title: John Deere faces U.S. lawsuit over farmers' ability to repair tractors
Description: The Federal Trade Commission and two states accuse Deere of costing farmers time and money by unfairly limiting software access and forcing the use of only authorized dealers. (Image credit: Seth Perlman)

Title: FBI background checks of presidential nominees, explained
Description: Confirmation hearings for Cabinet members nominated by President-elect Trump are underway. The FBI conducts background checks focusing on 'character and conduct' of the nominees. What's involved? (Image credit: Stefani Reynolds)

Title: What to know about RedNote, the Chinese app that American TikTokkers are flooding
Description: With TikTok's days in the U.S. potentially numbered, many American users are moving to another Chinese social media app: RedNote, a heavily censored platform similar to Instagram. Here's what to know. (Image credit: Andy Wong)

Title: Israel and Hamas reach a Gaza ceasefire agreement
Description: Israel and Hamas have reached an agreement on a multiphase ceasefire that commits them to end the war in Gaza, Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman James Risch said. (Image credit: Bashar Taleb)

Title: What L.A. did right before the fires -- and why it wasn't enough
Description: Los Angeles has wildfire policies that are far tougher than many of those in Western states. The destruction from the recent fires shows there are still major gaps to address. (Image credit: AGUSTIN PAULLIER/AFP via Getty Images)

Title: Gaza and the moon make biennial most-endangered list
Description: The World Monuments Fund list seeks to raise awareness and funds to help preserve the sites it spotlights. Africa's Swahili Coast, Maine's lighthouses and Buddhist grottoes in China are also in peril. (Image credit: Mohammed Abed)

Title: First Black woman to serve in the U.S. Army Nurse Corps after desegregation dies
Description: Nancy Leftenant-Colon, who became the first Black nurse in the U.S. Army Air Corps after President Harry S. Truman desegregated it in 1948, has died at age 104. (Image credit: CAF RISE ABOVE)

Title: Trump cabinet nominees face hearings. And, coping with Dry January's social pressure
Description: Six of President-elect Donald Trump's cabinet nominees face confirmation hearings today. Here's whom to watch. And, how to cope with social pressure during Dry January. (Image credit: Mandel Ngan)

Title: On Apache lands, progress in a long war against ticks and the disease they spread
Description: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever, the deadliest tick-borne disease in the U.S., is a big problem on tribal lands in the Southwest. A community-led response on Apache lands in Arizona is helping save lives. (Image credit: Caitlin O'Hara for NPR)

Title: Trump's Cabinet pick for secretary of state is Marco Rubio. Here's what to know
Description: Among President-elect Donald Trump's Cabinet picks, secretary of state nominee Marco Rubio may face the easiest confirmation process. (Image credit: Al Drago)

Title: Lower nicotine requirements in cigarettes could be coming soon
Description: The FDA is expected to propose a new rule Wednesday that would mean cigarettes have lower nicotine limits to make them less addictive.

Title: South Korean President Yoon detained after standoff over martial law decree
Description: Yoon and his ruling party supporters remain defiant against the insurrection charges. He is South Korea's first sitting president to be detained. (Image credit: /AP)

Title: Supreme Court to hear arguments on Texas porn law
Description: At issue is a Texas law that mandates pornography websites verify the ages of their users before they gain access to the material. (Image credit: Jon Elswick/AP)

Title: Departing DHS Secretary Mayorkas contends he delivered border security in the end
Description: As DHS Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas prepares to leave office, NPR sits down for an exit interview. He tells us the border is more secure now than before the pandemic. (Image credit: Shuran Huang for NPR)

Title: These workers are aiding labor investigations. Will Trump let them stay in the U.S.?
Description: Under Biden, thousands of workers who experienced wage theft and other abuses have been granted protection from deportation and authorization to work so they can participate in labor investigations.

Title: Photos: Southern California pets receive aid from rescue groups
Description: A network of rescue groups are caring for animals affected by wildfires still burning in the Los Angeles area. A multi-state operation is under way to help relieve local animal shelters. (Image credit: Ryan Kellman)

Title: Safety advocates fear Tesla will face less accountability for car crashes under Trump
Description: With Tesla CEO Elon Musk backing President-elect Donald Trump, safety advocates fear the incoming administration is poised to scrap a federal crash reporting requirement that Tesla calls unfair. (Image credit: Washington State Patrol)

Title: Trump's Cabinet pick for attorney general is Pam Bondi. Here's what to know
Description: Bondi is expected to receive broad support from Republicans but face sharp questions from Democrats who have concerns about whether she will protect the Justice Department from political influence. (Image credit: Mandel Ngan)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Seven of Trump's Cabinet nominees face confirmation hearing Wednesday, an update on the latest from the LA-area wildfires, South Korea's impeached President Yoon detained over martial law declaration.

Title: Trump promised to crack down on border crossings. The numbers are already way down
Description: Donald Trump won the election largely on the promise of cracking down on border crossings. But when he takes office next week, he will be inheriting a quiet border, with crossings plummeting for the last few months.

Title: South Korea's impeached President Yoon detained over martial law declaration
Description: South Korea's impeached President Yoon Suk Yeol has been detained for questioning by police over insurrection charges

Title: Biden administration removes Cuba from designation as state sponsor of terrorism
Description: The Biden administration has announced that it is lifting the U.S. designation of Cuba as a state sponsor of terrorism. But when the Trump administration takes over, will the decision be reversed?

Title: Hear the latest updates on the LA-area wildfires
Description: Get the latest updates on the LA-area wildfires that have killed at least 25 and forced thousands from their homes.

Title: The father of a hostage taken by Hamas talks about his son's potential return
Description: As cease-fire talks continue, NPR's Leila Fadel talks with Jonathan Dekel-Chen, whose son Sagui is believed to be alive and among the Israeli hostages who were seized by Hamas in the Oct. 7 attacks.

Title: The father of a hostages taken by Hamas talks about his son's potential return
Description: As cease-fire talks continue, NPR's Leila Fadel talks with Jonathan Dekel-Chen, whose son Sagui is believed to be alive among the Israeli hostages who were seized by Hamas in the Oct. 7 attacks.

Title: LA-area fire victims search for information sources they can trust
Description: Where do you turn for information during a disaster? People affected by the wildfires and evacuations in Los Angeles are asking that question, and who they can trust.

Title: Supreme Court to hear challenge to Texas law requiring age verification on porn sites
Description: The Supreme Court will hear arguments today in a challenge to a Texas law requiring adults to verify their identity before accessing porn online.

Title: Biden moves to lift state sponsor of terrorism designation for Cuba
Description: President Biden notified Congress of his intent to lift the U.S. label of Cuba as a state sponsor of terrorism as part of a deal aided by the Catholic Church to free political prisoners on the island. (Image credit: Susan Walsh)

Title: Dozens of survivors and dead pulled from abandoned South African mine
Description: The mine has been the scene of a tense standoff between police and miners since authorities launched an operation to force the miners out by cutting off food and water from the surface. (Image credit: Themba Hadebe)

Title: South Korean law enforcement officers detain impeached President Yoon
Description: Yoon was brought into custody about three hours after hundreds of law enforcement officers entered the residential compound in their second attempt to detain him over his imposition of martial law last month. (Image credit: Lee Jin-man)

Title: SEC sues Elon Musk, says he didn't disclose Twitter ownership on time before purchase
Description: The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission says Musk failed to disclose his ownership of Twitter stock in a timely manner before buying the site and underpaid by $150 million for shares he bought. (Image credit: Matt Rourke)

Title: No such thing as a free toilet: Starbucks reverses open bathroom policy
Description: The new guideline is a reversal of a 2018 open-door policy that was implemented after two Black men, who had not ordered anything, were arrested at a Philadelphia store. (Image credit: Christopher Furlong)

Title: Jack Smith said he could have convicted Trump. We looked at the report
Description: Special counsel Jack Smith said he would have won a criminal conviction of President-elect Donald Trump if not for his election to a second term.

Title: Supporters of ousted dictator Bashar Al-Assad flee Syria
Description: A new type of Syrian refugee is fleeing across the border into Lebanon: those who once supported dictator Bashar Al-Assad.

Title: How the War is Straining Ukraine's Military and Shaping its Children
Description: The city of Kherson in southern Ukraine is a key objective for Russia. Its military shells the city's neighborhoods daily and sends drones buzzing over the streets. We go out with a Ukrainian military unit that seeks to disrupt the Russians under the cover of darkness. And we also take a look at how three years of war have shaped Ukraine's children.

Title: The U.S. has tried to weaken Russia's wartime economy. Are sanctions working?
Description: For nearly three years, the U.S. and its allies have slapped roughly 5,000 sanctions and export controls on Russia for its invasion of Ukraine. Russia faces new sanctions targeting oil and gas trade.

Title: Why some doctors have started asking patients about their spiritual lives
Description: Indiana University's hospital system is pairing patients with local faith groups to ease feelings of loneliness and isolation. The unique new program comes as more doctors are seeing a need to care for patients' spiritual as well as physical health. (Image credit: Ben Thorp)

Title: What is a 'Particularly Dangerous Situation' red flag warning and other wildfire terms
Description: Here's a guide to understanding 'particularly dangerous situation' red flag warnings, containment, and other terms related to the devastating fires that have left much of the LA area in ruins. (Image credit: Josh Edelson)

Title: The Princess of Wales says her cancer is in remission
Description: The Princess of Wales revealed that her cancer is in remission after an emotional visit to the hospital where she received treatment last year. (Image credit: Chris Jackson)

Title: Two passenger jets came dangerously to each other in the skies over Phoenix
Description: The Federal Aviation Administration is once again looking into a close call at a major U.S. airport, after two passenger jets narrowly avoided a mid-air collision as they attempted to land in Phoenix. (Image credit: Justin Sullivan)

Title: Trump's 2nd-term foreign policy includes power plays in Greenland, Panama and beyond
Description: N.Y. Times journalist David Sanger says Trump's idea of America first is now less isolationism, more expansionism. He expects changes in the approach to Russia, China and the wars in Gaza and Ukraine.

Title: Five things we learn about Pope Francis from his new memoir
Description: In Pope Francis' autobiography Hope he reiterates themes of his papacy like hatred of war and unchecked capitalism, and a desire for the Catholic Church to be seen as a field hospital, not a fortress. (Image credit: Buda Mendes)

Title: Special counsel defends Trump indictment in report. And, Israel-Hamas ceasefire nears
Description: Special counsel Jack Smith says evidence against President-elect Donald Trump was enough to convict him. And, an Israeli official says an Israel-Hamas ceasefire agreement is nearing. (Image credit: Drew Angerer)

Title: Voices from the new breadlines in Syria: Who's waiting? And why?
Description: Syria's new rulers faces one of their first serious challenges: bread lines. For Syrians, the long wait is a struggle — but for some, bread is a business opportunity. (Image credit: Ayman Oghanna for NPR)

Title: This skateboarding economist suggests we need more skateparks and less capitalism
Description: A skateboarder presented an unusual paper at this year's big meeting of American economists. (Image credit: Adam Hester)

Title: Israel and Hamas may be on the verge of a ceasefire. Here's what we know right now
Description: Negotiators in Qatar are close to a ceasefire deal that sees an exchange of Israeli hostages for Palestinian detainees, a six-week pause in fighting and eventual troop withdrawal from Gaza. (Image credit: Ariel Schalit)

Title: Israel and Hamas are close to reaching a cease-fire agreement
Description: Negotiators in Qatar are close to a ceasefire deal that envisions an exchange of Israeli hostages for Palestinian detainees, a six-week pause in fighting and eventual withdrawal of troops from Gaza in the final phase. (Image credit: Ariel Schalit)

Title: Hamas and Israel could be close to a cease-fire deal
Description: Negotiators in Qatar are close to a cease-fire deal that envisions an exchange of Israeli hostages for Palestinian detainees, a six-week pause in fighting and eventual withdrawal of troops from Gaza in the final phase.

Title: Negotiators close to a cease-fire deal between Hamas and Israel
Description: Negotiators in Qatar are close to a cease-fire deal that envisions an exchange of Israeli hostages for Palestinian detainees, a six-week pause in fighting and eventual withdrawal of troops from Gaza in the final phase.

Title: A tortoise survival tale: How Tiptoe escaped Southern California's wildfires
Description: For years, Tiptoe has been a beloved sight in Pacific Palisades, quietly tromping along sidewalks and growing a major social media following. But last week, he lost his home to wildfires. (Image credit: Caitlin Doran)

Title: Extreme fire warnings keep LA residents on high alert
Description: Much of southwest California is under a red flag warning, with winds expected to peak Tuesday into Wednesday. Authorities are urging residents to heed evacuation orders and prepare for power outages. (Image credit: John Locher)

Title: NPR shopped for 96 items at Walmart to track how prices are really changing
Description: NPR has tracked the prices of dozens of items at the same superstore in Georgia, including eggs, T-shirts, snacks and paper towels. Here's what got cheaper over the past year, and more expensive. (Image credit: Alina Selyukh/NPR)

Title: How climate change is reshaping home insurance in California — and the rest of the U.S.
Description: Worsening wildfires are hiking up home insurance rates in California, the biggest market in the U.S. And as climate disasters increase across the country, other states are feeling the pressure too. (Image credit: Agustin Paullier)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: The DOJ released its election interference report against President-elect Trump, LA wildfires taking toll on mental health of survivors, NPR tracks actual prices of dozens of Walmart products.

Title: California has 'always been there' for disaster-affected states, Sen. Padilla says
Description: California Democratic Sen. Alex Padilla hopes President-elect Donald Trump will 'do the right thing' and support fire recovery efforts with no strings attached. (Image credit: Jae C. Hong)

Title: California Democratic Sen. Alex Padilla discusses efforts to fight LA wildfires
Description: NPR's A Martinez asks Democratic Sen. Alex Padilla of California about the fight to contain Los Angeles fires and fire recovery efforts.

Title: Many fleeing LA wildfires faced a tough decision — what to take and leave behind
Description: Many of the people who fled the wildfires in Southern California had little time to decide which possessions to take with them.

Title: Jack Smith's election interference report against Trump is out
Description: The report on federal charges against Trump for election interference in 2020 offers special counsel Jack Smith a last chance to explain his decisions after dropping the case. (Image credit: Drew Angerer)

Title: Lawsuits allege power company involvement in LA wildfires
Description: Lawsuits allege the Eaton Fire was sparked by a SoCal Edison transmission tower. The company says they have not had a chance to inspect the scene yet. The ATF has only just begun the federal investigation into the fire's cause. (Image credit: ZOE MEYERS)

Title: Special counsel in Hunter Biden case denounces president for criticism of the probe
Description: In a final report on his investigation, special counsel David Weiss said President Biden's criticism 'undermines the very foundation of what makes America's justice system fair and equitable.' (Image credit: Mandel Ngan)

Title: A pitmaster and dedicated father died alongside his son waiting for help in LA fire
Description: Anthony Mitchell Sr. and his son Justin were waiting for help to evacuate on the day they died in the Eaton fire, family members said. Anthony Sr. was remembered for his devotion to his children. (Image credit: Anthony Mitchell Jr.)

Title: Remembering an Altadena father and son who died in the Eaton Fire
Description: The wildfires in Los Angeles have destroyed thousands of homes, buildings and cars. They've also taken the lives of many people, including a father and son in Altadena, Anthony and Justin Mitchell.

Title: California's wildfires may also be catastrophic for its insurance market
Description: California's insurance industry was already in crisis. Now the wildfires in the Los Angeles region may upend efforts to stabilize the market. (Image credit: Greg Allen)

Title: What happens when wildland fire reaches the city?
Description: Wildfire' is the word we tend to use when we talk about what Los Angeles has been dealing with the past week. But Lori Moore-Merrell, the U.S. Fire Administrator for the Federal Emergency Management Agency used a different word, when she spoke to NPR this morning. She described a 'conflagration.' Saying they're not wildland fires with trees burning. They're structure to structure fire spread.They may have started at the suburban fringe, but they didn't stay there. Which prompts a question: what happens when fire meets city?For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.orgEmail us at considerthis@npr.org<...

Title: Breaking down the debate among conservatives over the H-1B visa program
Description: In recent weeks, there's been a debate among conservatives over the H-1B visa program. State Department data shows that workers from India received the majority of H-1B visas issued last year.

Title: Winds will remain a major problem through Wednesday, L.A. fire chief says
Description: A lull in winds over the weekend allowed firefighters to make some progress, but they're expected to pick up again. Fire danger remains extreme until at least Wednesday.

Title: Family remembers Victor Shaw, killed in the Eaton fire, for his bond with his sister
Description: Family members said Victor Shaw, 66, was shy and reserved in nature, but had a deep love for sports and a tight-knit bond with his younger sister.

Title: The Power Struggle Among Palestinian Groups in the West Bank
Description: There is a fight for power happening among Palestinian groups in the Israeli-occupied West Bank. The Palestinian Authority, which governs parts of the West Bank, has spent weeks weeks besieging the Jenin refugee camp. The tussle is also a fight over different visions for the Palestinian people. For more coverage of all sides of this conflict, go to npr.org/mideastupdates

Title: A TikTok ban could hit the U.S. in days. What to know — and how to prepare
Description: Even if the controversial U.S. ban on TikTok does take effect on Jan. 19, the app won't automatically vanish from phones. Here's what would change, plus preparations and potential workarounds. (Image credit: Joe Raedle)

Title: Party City is closing. Share your special memory with NPR
Description: What would you say in a eulogy for Party City? Have you shopped at Party City for memorable costumes, decorations, party favors or classroom awards? NPR wants to hear. (Image credit: Alina Selyukh/NPR)

Title: A Texas man is arrested in Indianapolis on a charge of stalking WNBA's Caitlin Clark
Description: The 55-year-old man sent the basketball star threatening and sexually explicit messages on social media, then traveled from Texas to Indianapolis to try to encounter her in person, prosecutors say. (Image credit: Joe Buglewicz)

Title: Judge Cannon paves the way for potential release of Part 1 of special counsel's report
Description: Cannon denied a motion by President-elect Donald Trump's former co-defendants who sought to block the release of special counsel Jack Smith's report on the election interference case. (Image credit: Saul Loeb/Eva Marie Uzcategui)

Title: As dangerous winds are expected to pick up, Los Angeles braces for new fires
Description: Damaging winds gusting between 55 and 70 mph are forecast, increasing fire risks across LA and Ventura counties over the next few days. More than 150,000 people are already under evacuation orders. (Image credit: David Pashaee)

Title: What to know about the Israel and Hamas Gaza ceasefire and hostage release talks
Description: The basic framework, officials familiar with the talks say, is an exchange of Israeli hostages for Palestinian prisoners, and a six-week ceasefire. Mediators are applying pressure on all parties. (Image credit: Abdel Kareem Hana)

Title: Israel and Hamas make progress in their ceasefire and hostage release talks
Description: Three officials said the next days would be critical for ending more than a year of fighting that has shaken the Middle East, but talks have stalled near the finish line repeatedly in the past year. (Image credit: Abdel Kareem Hana)

Title: Winds threaten the containment of wildfires. And, DHS chief reflects on his career
Description: Santa Ana winds are expected to pick back up, threatening the containment of Southern California wildfires. And, Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas reflects on his career. (Image credit: Eric Thayer)

Title: See some of the most terrifying and dramatic pictures of California wildfire devastation
Description: These photos chronicle the catastrophic scale of destruction from wildfires in California that started on January 7. (Image credit: Jae C. Hong/AP)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Officials are investigating at least 24 possible deaths from the LA-area wildfires, an update on cease-fire talks between Hamas and Israel, and NPR holds an exit interview with DHS Secretary Mayorkas.

Title: Officials investigating at least 24 deaths in Palisades and Eaton fires buring in LA
Description: The Palisades and Eaton fires are among the most destructive in California history. At least 24 people have been killed and thousands displaced in the wildfires raging in the Los Angeles area.

Title: U.S. Fire Administrator Lori Moore-Merrell discusses FEMA's response to LA-area fires
Description: NPR's A Martinez talks to U.S. Fire Administrator Lori Moore-Merrell about the Federal Emergency Management Agency's response to the wildfires in California.

Title: Biden expected to speak at State Department about foreign policy achievements
Description: President Biden returns to the State Department Monday to deliver what the White House says is a summation of his administration's work to strengthen America.

Title: Despite strict laws, Texas is awash in intoxicating cannabis
Description: Recreational marijuana is still illegal in Texas. The socially conservative legislature has voted it down year after year. And yet, with its exploding market for largely unregulated consumable hemp, Texas has inadvertently become the new Republic of THC. (Image credit: John Burnett)

Title: Despite strict laws, Texas is awash in intoxicating cannabis
Description: Texas, the law-and-order land of guns, God and capital punishment, is awash in cannabis. A loophole in a law allowing farmers to grow non-intoxicating hemp has been exploited, and now intoxicating hemp products are everywhere.

Title: DHS Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas says border more secure than before pandemic
Description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with outgoing Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas, who says the border is more secure now than in 2019.

Title: Iowa's AG hopes voters reverse ruling so kids don't have to face abusers in court
Description: Iowa's attorney general plans to go to voters to reverse a court ruling requiring children to face alleged abusers when they testify in court.

Title: As LA-area wildfires rage on, dangerously high winds could return this week
Description: As authorities in Los Angeles launched searches for the dead, crews made some progress fighting the fires. But there are worries about the return of dangerously high winds this week.

Title: How have displaced older folks fared in the LA fires?
Description: Older Angelenos are especially vulnerable as wildfires continue to tear through Los Angeles. Some older people had to be evacuated from assisted living facilities as others packed into shelters.Older Angelenos are especially vulnerable as wildfires continue to tear through Los Angeles. Some older people had to be evacuated from assisted living facilities as others packed into shelters.

Title: An update on cease-fire talks between Israel and Hamas
Description: President Joe Biden and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu discussed the peace talks in Qatar amid signs that Israel and Hamas had moved somewhat closer to a cease-fire deal.

Title: China's exports in December up 10.7%, beating estimates as higher U.S. tariffs loom
Description: China has raced to fill orders ahead of President-elect Donald Trump's promised tariffs on Chinese goods. Exports have surged in the country since the pandemic. (Image credit: AP)

Title: India kicks off a Hindu festival touted as the world's largest religious gathering
Description: Over the coming weeks, Hindu pilgrims with gather at the confluence of three rivers where they will begin a journey to reach Hindu philosophy's ultimate goal: the release from the cycle of rebirth. (Image credit: Ashwini Bhatia)

Title: Italy releases Iranian man wanted by U.S. over drone attack that killed 3 soldiers
Description: The release of Mohammad Abedini follows Iran's recent freeing of Italian journalist Cecilia Sala, sparking speculation that Sala may have been a bargaining chip. (Image credit: Alessandra Tarantino)

Title: Altadena resident shares her story about escaping the LA wildfires
On the way out: Transportation Sec. Buttigieg looks back on achievements, challenges
Description: From handling crises in the rail and airline industries to overseeing the distribution of billions of dollars in infrastructure funding, Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg has taken on a lot over the last four years.Now, his tenure is coming to an end.Host Scott Detrow speaks with Buttigieg about what the Biden administration accomplished, what it didn't get done, and what he's taking away from an election where voters resoundingly called for something different. Title: Why Los Angeles, America's most fire-ready city, became overwhelmed by flames
Description: In a city prone to large natural disasters, L.A. firefighters are widely considered to be among the best in the business at knocking down urban wildfires. But in the extreme conditions lately, experts say little can be done even to slow these modern fires. (Image credit: Eric Thayer)

Title: L.A. is bracing for the return of more powerful winds as fires continue to burn
Description: As firefighters continue to battle blazes in multiple fires, more Santa Ana winds in the coming days threaten to increase fire risk. (Image credit: John Locher)

Title: Southern California wildfires destroy or damage many houses of worship
Description: Faith communities in Los Angeles are trying to protect their homes and houses of worship from deadly wildfires. They are also trying to provide spiritual support for their traumatized congregations. (Image credit: Chris Pizzello)

Title: FEMA administrator discusses their plan of action for the California fires
Description: NPR's Ayesha Rascoe speaks with FEMA Administrator Deanne Criswell about the federal assistance available to victims of the Los Angeles wildfires.

Title: Swatting threats against Congress are becoming increasingly common — and costly
Description: Members of Congress are facing an increasing amount of swatting, where police are forced to respond to threatening calls or emails — which often turn out to be a hoax.

Title: Kate Bowler wants to have more 'uncounted, completely-wasted, doesn't-matter time'
Description: On Wild Card this week, Kate Bowler opens up about how she wants to waste her time, her feelings about God and how she talks about death with her child. (Image credit: Kate Bowler)

Title: New evacuations ordered in LA fires, at least 13 dead
Description: Mandatory evacuations remain in place in some communities in the LA basin while firefighting continues. But in Altadena, an extended family ignored evacuation orders and took heroic measures to save their home.

Title: How one U.S. conservationist's work is helping to preserve Chile's wilderness
Description: Chile is set to gain its 47th national park early this year — largely due to the efforts of U.S. conservationist Kristine Tompkins and her organization. (Image credit: Tamara Merino for NPR)

Title: People are rushing to install solar panels before Trump becomes President
Description: Potential rooftop solar customers and installers worry the incoming Trump administration might try to eliminate a 30% federal tax credit. Some customers plan to install sooner because of that and solar companies are changing their business plans. (Image credit: David Paul Morris)

Title: In Los Angeles, business owners try to pick up the pieces after wildfires
Brave Little State' explores the state of the U.S. Postal Service
Description: Brave Little State is a podcast that answers listener questions about Vermont.

Title: USDA report finds Boar's Head listeria outbreak was due to poor sanitation practices
Description: A report released by the Department of Agriculture found that poor sanitation practices at a Boar's Head facility in Virginia contributed to the largest listeria outbreak since 2011. (Image credit: Justin Sullivan)

Title: Firefighters make progress on LA blazes, and alert system is changed
Description: Firefighters made progress overnight on almost all of the active fires, including the massive Palisades and Eaton blazes, officials said. (Image credit: Lokman Vural Elibol)

Title: A winter storm wraps up in the South, with travel delays and power outages persisting
Description: The significant winter storm had passed in the South by Saturday morning, but travel issues and power outages were still ongoing. (Image credit: Megan Varner)

Title: How Jimmy Carter's love of music helped launch his presidential campaign
Description: Former President Jimmy Carter's close friends included the likes of Bob Dylan, Willie Nelson and the Allman brothers. (Image credit: Tom Hill)

Title: Why are so many indigenous Panamanians contracting HIV — and dying of AIDS?

Description: The 30th anniversary of the Mexican Rodeo Extravaganza at the National Western Stock Show is a celebration of pageantry and cultural heritage. (Image credit: Amanda Lopez for NPR)

Description: The defamation case brought by voting technology company Smartmatic against Fox News can proceed, a New York state appellate court rules. (Image credit: Spencer Platt/Getty Images)

Description: School districts in and around Los Angeles shut down because of the fires. That includes LAUSD, the second largest school district in the country. (Image credit: Jireh Deng for NPR)

Description: In response to the devastating fires raging in LA, a small restaurant in Surf City USA has become a channel for big help — from locals to people across the country — to support their neighbors up north. (Image credit: Emma Bowman/NPR)

Description: Close to a million migrants will be shielded from deportation for up to 18 months. (Image credit: Ben Curtis)

Description: People from Venezuela, El Salvador and Honduras has had Temporary Protected Status, TPS, for the longest time. With the Trump administration promising to end TPS, Central Americans are bracing for the possibility of being deported.

Title: U.S. ambassador to Israel makes his final push for release of U.S. hostages from Gaza
Description: We are going to do everything we can in this round to get all the American hostages, living and dead, out,' Ambassador Jacob J. Lew tells NPR. His tenure as President Biden's envoy ends this month. (Image credit: Maya Levin for NPR)

Title: U.S. ambassador to Israel talks about diplomatic efforts in the Israel-Hamas conflict
Description: As the U.S. ambassador to Israel, Jack Lew, prepares to leave his post, he talks about his diplomatic efforts to shape the direction of the Israel-Hamas war.

Description: The prison population has been creeping back upward. New laws in some states instituting harsher punishments threaten to further fill prisons, many of which are already understaffed and overcrowded.

Description: Atlanta has seen nearly 1,000 flights grounded, while more than 34,000 Arkansans have lost power. (Image credit: Joe Raedle)

Description: As fire crews and air tankers work to block the wildfires' explosive growth, images of red clouds of fire retardant falling onto trees are common. What is it — and what's in it? (Image credit: David Swanson)

Description: Southern California wildfire victims report looting after returning home to assess damages. And, President-elect Donald Trump is set for sentencing in a hush money conviction today. (Image credit: Ethan Swope)

Description: California has turned to incarcerated firefighters since 1915. To those opposed to the use of inmates as firefighters, the system is seen as exploitative. (Image credit: Jae C. Hong)

Description: Despite some progress, the biggest blazes — the Palisades and Eaton fires — rage uncontrolled as anxious residents receive alerts sent in error and face massive damages. (Image credit: Josh Edelson)

Title: How these suburban moms in Ukraine manage grief by training to down Russian drones
Description: Women from a Kyiv suburb traumatized by a 2022 massacre by Russian troops joined a volunteer air defense unit to take down Russia's drones — and deal with their fears. (Image credit: Oksana Parafeniuk for NPR)

Title: Who's in, who's out and who wants to rename the Gulf of Mexico? The quiz is back!
Description: This week, we tackle the Golden Globes, free speech, Girl Scout cookies, dragons and more. Add a perfect score to your New Year's resolutions! (Image credit: Amy Sussman/Getty Images, Harry How/Getty Images, Amy Sussman/Getty Images)

Description: Trump on Thursday exhausted his last legal maneuver to stop the sentencing, after a narrow majority of Supreme Court justices declined to intervene. (Image credit: Rebecca Noble)

Description: Jinghuan Liu Tervalon packed a few documents, keepsakes and clothing before leaving her Altadena, Calif., home ahead of the fast-moving Eaton Canyon Fire. Her son returned to find rubble and ash. (Image credit: Jervey Tervalon)

Description: As the German election campaign gets underway, Elon Musk's endorsement of the far-right Alternative for Germany party has prompted outrage from the political centre. But with the AfD polling in second place and the Tesla tycoon set to host the party's chancellor candidate Alice Weidel at a talk on X, the other parties are struggling to find effective campaign strategies of their own.

Description: The company's policy reversal comes as the U.S. is diverging sharply from other countries over regulating social media. (Image credit: Justin Sullivan)

Description: Many Latino immigrants in Los Angeles worked to extinguish some of the fires with hoses. They aren't firefighters, they were just helping people in other neighborhoods.

Description: We visit the hometown of the ousted Syrian President, Bashir al-Assad. Qardaha lies in northwest Syria, considered the heartlands of the Alawite religious sect.

Description: When buying and selling homes, there is no national record of who owns a property, who has a title to it. The Planet Money team has the story of a new kind of villain trying to exploit that system.

Description: Several large wildfires continue to rage out of control in Los Angeles County. At least 10 people have been killed, according to the LA County Medical Examiner, and thousands have fled their homes.

Description: Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro prepares to be sworn in for a third term despite accusations of stealing the last election. Thousands took to the streets to demand a return to democracy.

Description: Tim Heaphy was the lead investigator for the House Jan. 6 committee. He also looked into the violence in Charlottesville in 2017. He's got a new book out with insights into that experience.

Description: LA area residents are returning to their neighborhoods to see what's left of their homes. One of the hardest-hit neighborhoods is Altadena [al tuh DEE nuh], which was ravaged by the Eaton Fire.

Description: Actor Alec Baldwin has filed a civil lawsuit for malicious prosecution and civil rights violations in the fatal shooting of a cinematographer on the set of the Western movie Rust. (Image credit: Ramsay de Give/AP)

Title: He saved our lives.' A former US hostage reflects on Carter's legacy
Description: Jimmy Carter's four years in the White House were largely defined by an event that took place halfway through his term. On November 4th, 1979 Iranian college students took over the US Embassy in Tehran, and took 52 Americans hostage.For the next 444 days, the Carter administration tried to secure the hostages' release. In April, 1980 they even commissioned a rescue mission that ended in failure. While Carter was trying to end the hostage crisis, he was also campaigning for a second term. A year to the day after the Americans were taken hostage, Ronald Reagan beat Carter in a landslide.The hostage crisis played a key role in Carter's defeat. The Iranian Hostage crisis helped doom Jimmy Carter's presidency, but for some of the people he helped free,...

Title: Man who exploded Cybertruck in Las Vegas used ChatGPT in planning, police say
Description: The highly decorated soldier who exploded a Tesla Cybertruck outside the Trump hotel in Las Vegas used generative AI including ChatGPT to help plan the attack, Las Vegas police said Tuesday. (Image credit: Las Vegas Police Department)

Title: Cash is disintegrating due to overuse in Gaza. New businesses are repairing it
Description: Cash, the most precious commodity in Gaza, is disintegrating from overuse, and new banknotes have not been sent to Gaza during the war. That has led to e-banking and cash repair services.

Title: Wild weather brings snow to the South and Santa Ana winds to the West
Description: As the South prepped for snow and more cold starting Wednesday, residents in Southern California faced off with hurricane-strength winds. (Image credit: Julio Cortez)

Title: The Significance of Bread Lines in Syria
Description: Weeks ago, a new interim government in Syria was formed in the wake of the regime of Bashar al-Assad being toppled. And now that new government faces myriad challenges in holding the government together and keeping it running. Our correspondent in Damascus takes us to a bakery to show us one of the most visible signs of the new government's struggle, long bread lines. (Image credit: ARIS MESSINIS)

Title: Jean-Marie Le Pen, former far-right political leader in France, dies at 96
Description: Jean Marie Le Pen, the founder of France's post war far right movement died on Tuesday at the age of 96. He was repeatedly charged with hate speech, notably over comments about the Holocaust.

Title: What to know about Trump and his keen interest in Greenland
Description: President-elect Donald Trump has said multiple times that the U.S. should buy Greenland, an autonomous territory of Denmark. The sparsely populated island is geopolitically important and mineral-rich. (Image credit: Claire Harbage)

Title: Life threatening' windstorm triggers wildfire in Southern California
Description: Southern California hasn't seen significant rainfall since last April, and a pileup of dry fuel in combination with the winds has the region on edge. A mandatory evacuation order was issued for the Palisades. (Image credit: Ethan Swope)

Title: U.S. declares genocide in Sudan
Description: The Biden administration said it has determined that Sudan's paramilitary group, the Rapid Support Forces, is committing genocide in the country's ongoing civil war.

Title: Minneapolis agrees to additional court-ordered oversight of its police department
Description: The Minneapolis Police Department must make major reforms under a federal consent decree. That comes nearly five years after a Minneapolis police officer murdered George Floyd.

Title: Florida judge blocks release of special counsel report on Trump cases
Description: Florida federal judge Aileen Cannon ordered the Justice Department not to share Jack Smith's final report until a federal appeals court resolves the legal fight. (Image credit: Drew Angerer)

Title: The U.S. says Sudan's rebel forces have committed genocide
Description: The Biden administration said the Sudanese Rapid Support Forces group and its proxies are committing genocide in a civil war with the country's military that has killed tens of thousands of people. (Image credit: Sam Mednick)

Title: A Dutch project publicizes the names of half a million suspected Nazi collaborators
Description: The names of some 425,000 suspected Dutch collaborators went online 80 years after the Holocaust ended, making them accessible to historians and descendants as the country grapples with its past. (Image credit: Keystone/Getty Images)

Title: 2 bodies found in JetBlue plane's landing gear compartment at a Florida airport
Description: The bodies were located in the wheel well area at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. It's the second time over the past month that a body has been found in the wheel well of an airplane. (Image credit: Chris O'Meara)

Title: In a workforce transformed by war, Ukrainian women are now working in coal mines
Description: War has changed Ukraine's workforce, especially in heavy industry and mining. With men conscripted to fight the war against Russia, women have started working in traditionally male jobs. (Image credit: Michael Robinson Chávez for NPR)

Title: Jean-Marie Le Pen, French fiery far-right leader, dies at 96
Description: Le Pen was convicted numerous times of antisemitism, discrimination and inciting racial violence. But the nativist ideas that propelled his popularity remain ascendant in today's France and beyond. (Image credit: Kamil Zihnioglu)

Title: Jimmy Carter's funeral services begin in DC. And, photos from the major winter storm
Description: Former President Jimmy Carter's funeral services begin in Washington, D.C., today, and NPR will have special coverage of the events. And, photos from the winter storm plowing through parts of the U.S. (Image credit: Brynn Anderson)

Title: What America's top economists are saying about AI and inequality
Description: Planet Money attended the annual meeting of American economists — and the most popular topic this year was artificial intelligence.

Title: Jimmy Carter's funeral services begin in Washington, D.C., today
Description: The next stop in former President Jimmy Carter's six days of funeral services is Washington, D.C., where he will lie in state in the U.S. Capitol through Thursday morning. (Image credit: Jon Cherry)

Title: Strong earthquake kills dozens in western China near Mount Everest
Description: A strong earthquake killed dozens of people in Tibet on Tuesday and left many others trapped as dozens of aftershocks shook the high-altitude region of western China and across the border in Nepal. (Image credit: AP)

Title: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announces resignation
Description: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has announced he is stepping down ahead of this year's general election. He had faced mounting pressure to resign — from both allies and opponents.

Title: How ISIS is adapting its tactics to survive
Description: Is ISIS having a resurgence? NPR's A Martinez talks to Aaron David Miller, senior fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, about how ISIS is adapting its tactics to survive.

Title: How ISIS is adapting its tactics to survive
Description: Is ISIS having a resurgence? NPR's A Martinez talks to Aaron David Miller, senior fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, about how ISIS is adapting its tactics to survive.

Title: Orthodox Christmas takes on special meaning in Lebanon this year
Description: Many Orthodox Christians celebrate Christmas in January, not December. In Lebanon, Christians say the holiday is extra poignant for them this year.

Title: In 2007 interview, Jimmy Carter discusses what he faced after losing reelection
Description: Hear excerpts from a 2007 NPR interview with former President Jimmy Carter talking about the stark question he faced after failing to win reelection: what to do with the rest of his life.

Title: Syria's interim government faces a new, serious challenge — bread lines
Description: Bread lines have become a feature of the new Syria, posing a critical challenge to the country's rebel rulers who ousted President Bashar al-Assad last month.

Title: Growing number of Colombians are fighting — and dying — in conflicts around the world
Description: More and more former members of Colombia's armed forces are fighting and dying as mercenaries around the world.

Title: Virginia elections could determine if Democrats hold slim majority in Legislature
Description: Special elections in Virginia could decide whether Democrats maintain their control of the Legislature as the commonwealth heads into a governor's race this fall.

Title: Hamas and Israel are negotiating the release of hostages from Gaza
Description: Israel and Hamas are eyeing a hostage release and ceasefire deal before Donald Trump's inauguration.

Title: Former adviser and analyst discusses why key committee was split on U.S. Steel deal
Description: Why was the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States split on allowing or blocking Nippon Steel from buying U.S. Steel? NPR's Michel Martin asks one of the committee's former advisers.

Title: Ski patrollers strike at Utah's Park City Mountain resort
Description: Ski-industry giant Vail resorts is struggling with a strike by ski patrollers at Park City Mountain resort in Utah, their biggest property. Skiers are complaining about delays and unsafe conditions.

Title: Morning Edition colleagues share snow-day traditions
Description: With much of the central and eastern U.S. blanketed with snow, our Morning Edition colleagues share a few beloved snow day traditions.

Title: Minneapolis, DOJ agree on police reforms in wake of George Floyd murder
Description: The city of Minneapolis and the U.S. Department of Justice have agreed on a consent decree which calls for the Minneapolis Police Department to make extensive reforms. The agreement comes five years after the death of George Floyd caused protests around the city and the world.

Title: U.K. leader Starmer slams 'lies and misinformation' after attacks from Elon Musk
Description: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer on Monday condemned 'lies and misinformation' that he said are undermining U.K. democracy, in response to a barrage of attacks on his government from Elon Musk. (Image credit: Leon Neal/AP)

Title: Minneapolis agrees to overhaul police training and policies following Floyd murder
Description: The Minneapolis City Council on Monday approved an agreement with the federal government to overhaul the city's police training and use-of-force policies in the wake of the murder of George Floyd. (Image credit: Jeff Wheeler/AP)

Title: Rudy Giuliani is held in contempt of court in $148 million defamation case
Description: Rudy Giuliani was found in contempt of court for failing to properly respond to requests for information as he turned over assets to satisfy a defamation ruling granted to two Georgia poll workers. (Image credit: Adam Gray)

Title: The National Zoo's giant pandas make the most of DC's snow
Description: The two giant pandas were seen on camera playing around in the snowfall that blanketed much of the Midwest and mid-Atlantic on Monday. (Image credit: National Zoo)

Title: First bird flu death reported in the U.S., according to the CDC
Description: Health officials in Louisiana say a person there has died after catching bird flu. This marks the first reported death in the U.S. from the virus during the current outbreak. (Image credit: Callista Images)

Title: Elon Musk has been trolling British politicians, stirring anger and concern
Description: Fixated on a UK sex abuse scandal from 15 years ago, Elon Musk has been trolling British officials, prompting a rebuke from the prime minister and worry over what this portends for U.S. policy.

Title: It will now cost up to $9 to drive into New York City
Description: Motorists driving into many parts of Manhattan will now pay as much as $9, as part of a new congestion pricing plan to eliminate traffic and pay for improvements to mass transit.

Title: In Syria, a once-privileged Muslim sect is now targeted and afraid
Description: Alawites in Syria are facing a violent backlash, stoking fears of wider sectarian instability in a divided Syria after the fall of the Assad regime.

Title: Pentagon agrees to settle historic lawsuit with LGBTQ+ veterans over discharge status
Description: The Pentagon has agreed to settle a class action lawsuit involving about 35,000 LGBTQ+ veterans that will help them get benefits like health care and disability. (Image credit: Daniel Slim)

Title: 32 dolphins have died since an oil spill near southern Russia, experts say
Description: A dolphin rescue center said most of the dead dolphins were from the endangered Azov species. (Image credit: Krasnodar Gov. Veniamin Kondraty)

Title: A winter storm moves across the U.S., causing disruptions and snowball fights
Description: Millions of Americans are under weather advisories today as a winter storm blasts through the middle of the country.

Title: What may be next after a federal court struck down the FCC's net neutrality rules
Description: NPR's Juana Summers speaks with Stanford Law Professor Barbara van Schewick about a federal court's decision to strike down the Biden administration's net neutrality protections.

Title: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau will step down once his party has a new leader
Description: Under pressure from voters and his own members of parliament, Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced Monday that he will step down once his Liberal Party names a sucessor.

Title: Biden visits New Orleans after Jan. 1 attack
Description: President Joe Biden will travel to New Orleans on Monday and attend a prayer service for the 14 victims of the New Year's Day attack.

Title: The Epicenter of the COVID Outbreak Five Years Later
Description: We go to the city were there the COVID-19 global pandemic started five years ago, Wuhan, China. We find that security is still tight and trauma is still pervasive. We look at what has changed— and what hasn't— since the 'mysterious illness' first emerged.

Title: U.S. transfers 11 Yemeni prisoners from Guantánamo to Oman
Description: The Biden administration's move leaves just 15 detainees at the U.S. military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. Oman will help resettle the men and provide security monitoring. (Image credit: Thomas Watkins)

Title: Hamas and Israel are negotiating the release of 34 hostages from Gaza
Description: The deal would secure release of a third of the approximately 100 hostages who remain in Gaza, including two dual U.S.-Israeli nationals. In return, Israel would release some Palestinian prisoners. (Image credit: Amir Levy/Getty Images)

Title: Millions of public workers are set to get higher Social Security benefits. Here's why
Description: Public service workers including some teachers, firefighters, police officers may soon see their Social Security payments increase by hundreds of dollars. (Image credit: Kent Nishimura)

Title: Lessons from self-inflicted blows to democracy in South Korea and the U.S.
Description: The brief declaration of martial law in South Korea last month has drawn comparisons to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol. The attempted power grabs could hold lessons for other democracies. (Image credit: Anthony Wallace)

Title: Canada's Justin Trudeau says he will resign as party leader and prime minister
Description: Trudeau's decision after almost a decade in power sets the stage for a succession fight to select a new prime minister. (Image credit: Dave Chan)

Title: Photos: See the impact a major winter storm is having on U.S.
Description: Winter storm warnings have ben declared from Illinois to New Jersey. And some areas will get a lot of snow. They will also get freezing rain and ice, blustery winds and frigid temperatures. (Image credit: Joshua A. Bickel)

Title: How Jan. 6 will be different this year. And, who took home a Golden Globe award
Description: Today, four years since the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, President-elect Donald Trump's victory is scheduled to be certified by Congress. And, the big wins and surprises at the 82nd Golden Globes. (Image credit: Brendan Smialowski/Pool)
